华丽秋季摄影的 9 个秘诀首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

我喜欢秋季摄影；还有什么比躺在郁郁葱葱的绿草上或在深蓝的天空下飘扬的金色叶子更美丽的呢？

不幸的是，捕捉秋天的色彩可能有点棘手。为了拍出最好的照片，您必须仔细选择您的装备、灯光和设置 - 如果您是初学者，这一切都可能会让人不知所措。

但永远不要害怕！在这篇文章中，我分享了拍摄令人惊叹的秋季摄影的重要技巧。我解释：

  • 如何使用简单的滤镜呈现出可爱的秋天色彩
  • 如何调整白平衡设置以获得华丽的温暖图像
  • 如何通过追逐正确的光线来拍摄令人惊叹的照片
  • 多得多！

准备好成为秋季摄影大师了吗？那么让我们开始吧！

1.使用偏光滤镜增强色彩

首先要做的事情是：

如果您想捕捉丰富、大胆的秋季色彩，那么您应该首先购买偏光滤镜。

偏光镜位于镜头的前面，可以减少反射光。潮湿和/或蜡质叶子上的反射会降低颜色强度，因此通过阻止这些不需要的光线到达相机传感器，您的秋季照片将获得饱和度提升。

不过，请确保购买高质量的过滤器；廉价的偏光镜无法有效地发挥其作用，并且会产生恼人的色偏。因此，请购买制作精良的选件，例如Hoya 提供的圆偏光镜。

注意：偏光镜的直径必须与镜片的直径相匹配。选择您计划在秋季最常使用的镜片，计算出其直径，然后购买相应的偏光镜。

另外，请记住，偏光镜确实会减少到达相机传感器的光线总量。作为补偿，您的相机将被迫延长快门速度，这可能会导致相机抖动。为了防止这种情况，我建议使用好的三脚架进行拍摄！

2.在黄金时段拍摄

日出后的一小时左右和日落前的一小时左右被称为黄金时段。如果您曾经花时间观察过傍晚的光线，您就会知道原因：当太阳在天空中低落时，它会在大地上投射出美丽、柔和的金色光芒——这种光线在照亮秋季拍摄对象时看起来令人惊叹。

黄金时段的灯光有几个主要好处。它很柔软，因此可以帮助您拍摄包含许多美丽细节的照片。而且天气很温暖，因此您的图像将具有令人惊叹的金色色调。

就我个人而言，我非常喜欢低处的阳光如何凸显红色和金色。您可以捕捉令人惊叹的秋季风景、特写细节、秋季肖像等等。

如果你能起得足够早，早上实际上会比晚上好一点。其一，外出的人会减少，因此您通常会独享森林小道。早晨的风往往较小，如果您想将令人惊叹的秋天色彩与池塘倒影结合起来，这是理想的选择。

3.不要忽视阴天

如果您追求丰富、温暖的色彩，黄金时段的灯光是很棒的选择……

…但您也可以在阴天拍摄独特的图像。云就像巨大的漫射器，创造出柔和、均匀的光线，展现细节，增添气氛，甚至使色彩饱和。

例如，秋天的森林场景在阴暗的灯光下看起来令人惊叹。小细节——落叶、九月的花朵和枯萎的植物——看起来也很华丽。

温馨提示：如果天空多云，请确保在中午出去拍摄。随着太阳在天空中落下（即落到云层后面），世界变得越来越暗淡。下午晚些时候，您可能很难捕捉清晰的手持图像。 （尽管您始终可以选择使用三脚架！）

4.寻找色彩对比

秋天充满了各种美丽的色彩对比：绿色（草）背景上的红叶，蓝色（天空）背景上的橙色叶子，黄色（叶子）背景上的紫色花朵。

如果您可以将这么多的对比融入到您的图像中，您最终会得到一些令人惊叹的结果。

您会看到，色彩对比通过在主体和背景之间创建清晰的分离来增加三维度。另外，对比色本身就很引人注目！

如果您很难看到颜色对比，请考虑打印并携带色轮。相反的颜色形成了美丽的对比，尽管相邻的颜色确实融合得很好（并创造了一个更柔和的调色板）。

一旦您开始看到有规律的颜色对比，请尝试尝试不同的颜色平衡。您可以使用大量的红色和少量的绿色来打造更加内敛的外观，或者使用等量的红色和少量绿色来获得强烈的效果。

5.考虑太阳的位置

一些秋季摄影师喜欢避免将太阳纳入画面中。为什么？如果阳光照射到相机传感器，就会产生镜头眩光，从而冲淡场景并减少秋季色彩的影响。

另一方面，通过将太阳融入画面中，您可以创建有趣的日星效果，从而增强而不是削弱您的秋季风景和肖像。 （将光圈缩小到 f/8 左右，以获得漂亮的太阳星！）

所以我鼓励您尝试这两种方法。花一些时间在远离阳光的地方拍摄（这样你就可以捕捉到美丽的顺光和侧光拍摄对象）。然后转身对着太阳拍摄。看看你是否可以刻意制造镜头光晕。

6. 调整白平衡设置

白平衡是处理图像中偏色的过程。一些光源（例如低太阳）会产生非常温暖的橙色光，而其他光源（例如人造闪光灯）会产生非常冷的蓝色光。但是，当您拨入正确的白平衡时，您可以中和（即消除）这种温暖或寒冷的结果。成功的中和可以帮助底层颜色凸显出来，并确保照片更准确地表现其主题。

一般来说，中和色偏是一个好主意，因此使用相机的白平衡预设甚至使用灰卡设置白平衡会很有帮助。如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄，则始终可以在后期处理过程中调整白平衡，不会出现任何问题，但从一开始就做好准备可以节省时间。

另请注意，您并不总是需要使用白平衡来校正图像颜色。实际上，您可以使用暖色或冷色的白平衡设置来为秋季文件增添气氛。例如，如果您想增强红色和橙色，您可以使用高温白平衡预设来预热图像！

7. 旨在描绘混乱

秋天的景色往往相当混乱。它们通常以挥舞的树枝、落叶、色彩缤纷的灌木……这样的例子不胜枚举。

在摄影中，混乱通常是一件坏事。许多摄影师会花很长时间处理每个场景，以减少混乱。毕竟，混乱会分散观众的注意力并阻止他们看向主要主题，对吧？

不总是！如果您能拥抱混乱，您就可以拍摄出超越标准秋季照片的独特图像。尝试仔细构图，使所有元素像拼图一样组合在一起。看看你是否可以在整个框架中散布不同的颜色——这里有一些红色，那里有一些绿色。

在“混乱”镜头中，目标是用抽象几何来思考。确保仔细平衡整个场景中的不同颜色和纹理。并测试不同的光圈，看看图像是否像深景深照片或浅景深文件一样好看。

8. 在后期处理中呈现出秋天的色彩

大多数最佳的秋季照片效果都是在相机内完成的，您不应该将编辑软件视为“修复”或“创建”令人惊叹的图像的一种方式。

然而，您可以通过凸显色彩、增强深度和增加细节来增强您的秋季摄影效果。它也不需要专业知识；您可以在 Lightroom 等直观的程序中处理所有秋季照片编辑。

我建议首先调整曝光，以确保捕捉到所需的细节水平。如果您发现任何无细节的阴影或高光，请使用色调滑块（即高光、阴影、黑色和白色滑块）来恢复丢失的数据。

然后进行一些对比度更改。这通常会看起来很漂亮并且会增加很多冲击力，但不要太过分。太多的对比度会开始产生不切实际的效果，这绝对不是您想要的。

最后，尝试不同的颜色强度滑块。例如，“饱和度”滑块可以提高整体颜色强度。另一方面，Vibrance 滑块增强冷色。如果您特别喜欢冒险，您甚至可以尝试调整单个颜色（使用Lightroom 的 HSL 面板或Photoshop 的色相/饱和度调整图层）。

9.天气不好时外出

我知道我知道：

恶劣的天气会让您想呆在室内，而不是带着相机冒险出去。

但如果你尝试一下，你很快就会发现秋天的色彩与雾天、雨天，甚至（如果你幸运的话！）下雪的下午相结合，看起来会令人难以置信。

其一，恶劣的天气会增加很多气氛。雨是增添忧郁情绪的好方法，而雪可以营造令人振奋的氛围或更悲伤、更孤独的外观（取决于您处理和编辑照片的方式）。雾几乎总是看起来很棒，但如果您想要真正强大的图像，请尝试将雾与重复结合起来（例如森林中的树木线条）。

不过，你必须要小心。在大雾或大雪中很容易迷路，因此请务必携带电话并提前告诉别人您要去的地方。恶劣的天气可能会损坏您的相机，因此请务必随身携带防雨罩。 （我还鼓励您携带第二个盖子，包裹住您的相机包并保持干燥）。

秋季摄影技巧：最后的话

现在您已经完成了这篇文章，您已经准备好拍摄一些美丽的秋天图像了。

因此，享受拍摄秋天色彩的乐趣吧。并确保尽可能拍摄。在许多地区，秋季的高峰景象只持续几周。您不想错过！

美丽洞穴摄影的 13 个技巧首先出现在数码摄影学校。它的作者是彼得·韦斯特·凯里。

洞穴摄影令人兴奋、强大且令人惊叹。但洞穴确实给摄影师带来了一些独特的挑战。低光照水平使得难以捕捉详细的曝光，并且洞穴条件可能会不舒服或完全不安全。

在这篇文章中，我分享了拍摄精美洞穴照片的最佳技巧。具体我解释一下：

  • 进行详细拍摄时必须使用的技术（和装备）
  • 如何在图像中营造比例感
  • 如何保护自己和您的装备！ - 安全的
  • 多得多！

因此，如果您计划开始洞穴摄影冒险，或者您只是想提高您的洞穴摄影知识，那么请继续阅读！

1.保护你的装备

在洞穴摄影中，你（显然！）被岩石包围。根据我的经验，相机不喜欢与岩石接触。 （镜头或三脚架也不行。）

因此，在探索洞穴时，务必盖好相机和镜头，并将三脚架腿收好。我鼓励您将装备收好，直到您绝对需要为止；您将进入陌生的领域并在不平坦的表面上行走。有时，你会爬行。带上一个带衬垫的包或背包，并确保在准备拍照之前将相机放在里面。

洞穴也往往很潮湿，湿气经常从天花板上掉下来。因此，请带上毛巾或布来擦拭相机。您也可以考虑在拍摄时将其覆盖在相机和镜头上。 （如果您非常担心水损坏，甚至可以使用防雨罩。）通常，水滴会携带许多矿物质，最好尽早清除。

2.带上三脚架

洞穴非常黑暗，这意味着您需要更长的快门速度才能捕捉详细的曝光。快门速度越长， 相机抖动的风险就越大 - 因此，如果您想最大限度地提高拍摄清晰照片的机会，三脚架是必不可少的。

不幸的是，一些商业公司探索的洞穴不允许使用三脚架。提前检查规则，如果不能使用三脚架，请务必携带图像稳定的相机和镜头。我还鼓励您使用大光圈镜头（f/2.8 或更宽的镜头最好）并携带闪光灯以进行人工照明。

3.使用遥控快门线

三脚架很棒，但如果你不使用正确的技术，你最终会得到模糊的照片。

例如，按下快门按钮可能会产生相机抖动并导致图像模糊。这就是远程快门释放器派上用场的地方。它可以让您从远处触发相机快门。只需将相机安装在三脚架上，按下遥控释放按钮，您就可以拍摄洞穴照片 - 无需触摸快门按钮。

如果您没有遥控快门并且不打算购买，您可以随时使用相机的自拍功能，该功能会将拍摄瞬间延迟到按下快门按钮后几秒钟。这工作得很好，但每次拍摄后等待几秒钟可能会很烦人，所以我鼓励您如果可以的话使用远程释放！

4.使用离机闪光灯

正如我在之前的提示中提到的，闪光灯非常有用，尤其是在三脚架不可用的情况下。它们会照亮洞穴，这样您就可以在不使用长快门速度的情况下捕捉到曝光良好的图像。

但一定要带上离机闪光灯。相机上的闪光灯照片往往看起来是平面和二维的。但是，使用离机闪光灯时，您可以将闪光灯放在一边，从而使图像更具深度。 （并且可以使用多个闪光灯来照亮洞穴！）

5.戴头灯

进行洞穴摄影时，您总是需要两个光源：

闪光（如上所述）。

还有头灯。

头灯会照亮您的道路并防止您发生任何严重事故。手电筒也可以，但在设置三脚架和相机时，有两只空闲的手会很有帮助。

6. 将白平衡设置为闪光

我鼓励您在进行洞穴摄影时始终使用闪光灯（假设洞穴没有商业照明）。

因此，在进入地下之前，请将相机的白平衡设置设置为闪光灯选项。

这是简化生活的步骤之一，可以帮助您以最少的编辑来拍摄出好的照片。也就是说，如果您忘记设置白平衡，只要您遵循我的下一个提示，也不是世界末日：

7. 以RAW格式拍摄

想要拍摄看起来华丽且专业的洞穴照片吗？那么你必须以RAW格式拍摄。

当您在数字暗室中调整曝光和白平衡时，RAW 文件将为您提供最大的自由度。

如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄，则可以恢复 JPEG 格式中会丢失的细节。

8.降低ISO

您可能知道，较高的ISO会导致更多的噪点——微小的光斑和色彩看起来很糟糕，并且很快就会毁掉图像。

确实如此：ISO 越高，快门速度就越快，也就越容易避免相机抖动。

但如果您使用三脚架，则没有理由将 ISO 提高到荒谬的高度。相反，依靠三脚架来保持相机稳定，并保持尽可能低的 ISO。如果可能的话，我建议使用 ISO 100 或 200，并且只有在绝对必要时才将其调高！

9. 不要害怕延长快门速度

只要您使用坚固的三脚架，您就可以将快门速度降低至 5 秒、10 秒、30 秒等。

我鼓励您尝试不同的快门速度选项（特别是在将较长的快门速度与闪光灯结合使用时）。您希望获得具有大量阴影细节的图像，但同时，避免将闪光灯照亮的洞穴区域吹掉也很重要。

在保持所有设置不变（包括闪光灯亮度）但改变快门速度的同时进行多次测试拍摄会很有帮助。如果您发现很难正确曝光阴影和高光，您可能还需要考虑使用HDR 技术。

10.使用手动对焦

洞穴很暗——在黑暗条件下，相机的自动对焦系统会非常困难。

如果您非常想使用自动对焦，请尝试将头灯指向对比特征的边缘，然后使用该区域来设置焦点。

但一般来说，最好将镜头切换为手动对焦。这样，您就可以设置焦点，而不必担心相机失控。

注意：如果您使用广角镜头，并且主要的洞穴拍摄对象位于远处，您可能会发现手动对焦很困难。首先，将对焦环旋转至无限远。然后退后一点。拍摄后，在液晶显示屏上查看 - 尝试放大以检查完美的清晰度！ – 并根据需要进行调整。

11.在商业洞穴工作时进行调整

商业洞穴是为探索而设计的，因此它们往往具有充足的灯光。 （例如，国家公园里的洞穴往往灯火通明！）

这些洞穴通常很有趣，因为它们已经光线充足，不需要闪光灯。不过，三脚架仍然有用，因此请检查洞穴规则是否允许您携带三脚架。

如果您正在旅行，事情可能进展得很快，您可能没有太多时间拍照，而且您可能不得不面对人群。提前咨询旅行社，看看您是否可以在一天中的空闲时段前往。您也可能会问，如果您在旅行继续进行时稍事停留是否可以。答案通常可能是“不”，但询问可以为您打开一扇通往您原本不会考虑的可能性的大门，所以请给导游一个机会来帮助您！

12.带上广角镜头

洞穴有各种形状和大小，但大多数场景都是大型的 - 因此请带上您拥有的最广角的镜头。我建议 APS-C 传感器从 18 毫米左右开始，如果您的相机是全画幅，则从 28 毫米开始。这样，您就可以捕捉大量显示整个场景的广阔图像。

也就是说，洞穴确实为受益于长镜头的特写构图提供了机会。因此，如果有空间，请带上长焦镜头并根据需要进行切换。但请记住：洞穴充满了湿气，因此更换镜头时要小心，并将变化保持在最低限度。

13.将一个人放入图片中

有些洞穴很大，有些则很小——但在拍照时，如果没有参考点，洞穴的规模往往会丢失。

虽然特写镜头并不会因添加人物而真正受益，但如果在画面中加入站立的人，更宽的镜头看起来会好得多。

请注意，您需要摆好人物姿势并让他们在拍摄时保持静止。否则，它们最终会变得模糊（假设您使用长快门速度）。相反，如果您想捕捉创意效果，您可以要求拍摄对象四处移动。尝试不同的方法，看看哪种方法适合您！

洞穴摄影技巧：最后的话

好吧，你已经有了：

让您的洞穴照片更上一层楼的十三个技巧。

因此，下次您去洞穴探险时，请记住我分享的建议。确保您携带正确的设备、使用正确的设置并保持安全。还有，玩得开心！

火焰摄影不一定很可怕，而且也可以很有趣——如果你知道自己在做什么。

作为一名经验丰富的火焰摄影师，我发现了所有保证您获得华丽效果的技巧、窍门和技术，包括：

  • 正确的火灾拍摄设置
  • 拍摄火灾时如何保持安全
  • 如何在你的作品中加入火焰

当您读完本文时，您将了解如何像专业人士一样拍摄火焰（并且希望您能从数十个示例图像中获得灵感）。

1. 确保安全拍摄火灾

用弗兰肯斯坦的怪物的话来说，“火坏了！”对于摄影师来说尤其如此。

如果你想做火焰摄影，就必须认真对待火焰。热量和烟雾会损坏您的设备，火焰会很快失去控制并烧毁物品，而且 - 最重要的是！ – 火会直接杀死你。

在此网站上可以找到大量重要的火灾信息，但以下是您应该立即记住的一些基本安全提示：

  • 提前思考并从头到尾计划您的拍摄，这样您就可以准确地知道在任何给定时间什么会着火以及如何拍摄它
  • 制定一旦火势蔓延时的灭火计划
  • 请勿在不想着火的任何物体附近工作
  • 在通风良好的地方工作
  • 确保您工作的地方即使发生最坏的情况，一切都会好起来

知道了？我恳求您：在拍摄火灾照片之前采取适当的安全预防措施。你可能认为这些规则不适用于你，你会没事的，等等……但这种想法是一场即将发生的灾难。

我建议你从拍摄火作为你的主题开始，因为它看起来真的非常酷。

对于此类火焰镜头，主要焦点是火焰（或其效果）以及其中显示的细节。我说的是这样的镜头，它具有清晰的火焰细节：

（注意：随着快门速度的增加，您需要使用更宽的光圈和更高的ISO 。）

曝光可能很困难，因为您的相机通常需要对火焰进行曝光不足以补偿其令人难以置信的亮度。因此，不要害怕过度曝光一两站以获得完美的火焰细节。

我还建议您在开始拍摄火焰照片时进行一些测试拍摄。不要一开始就考虑构图；相反，集中精力确定火焰的暴露程度。

3. 以火焰为重点进行拍摄

您可能不想将火焰作为主要主题，而是尝试将火焰作为更大场景中的一个元素进行拍摄，如下所示：

这里的关键是曝光火焰，然后为场景的其余部分添加光线。因此，对火焰进行测光（在这里， 点测光是最佳选择），进行一些测试，以确保获得所需的结果，然后添加光线以照亮周围的元素。

如果您无法控制照明情况（例如，您在户外拍摄），那么您需要寻找可以将火焰置于对比背景下的拍摄角度。较暗的实心区域是更好的选择，但任何提供一定对比度的区域都应该有效。

4.使用火作为光源

火提供柔和的阴影和温暖的颜色，因此它是一种美妙的光源——尤其是在像这样的篝火场景中：

请注意火如何美丽地照亮周围的树木。

但是如何拍摄出如此神奇的火焰效果呢？以下是一些快速提示：

  1. 使用长快门速度。虽然火看起来很华丽，但它并不是很明亮。作为补偿，您通常需要工作 1 秒、5 秒甚至 30 秒。
  2. 扩大光圈。同样，这里的目标是弥补光线的不足。如果需要，将光圈调至最大设置。
  3. 提高 ISO。一般来说，从低 ISO 开始是个好主意，但如果您进行了一些测试，但它们并不明亮，那么就提高 ISO（并继续提高 ISO，直到获得您想要的结果） 。
  4. 仔细注意光线照射的地方。如果您在篝火周围拍摄，您可以在距离火焰十几英尺的拍摄对象上获得有趣的灯光 - 所以不必觉得必须剪得很紧。相反，要对周围的环境发挥创意。

此外，当使用大光圈并因此使用窄景深时，请尝试将焦点放在具有高对比度边缘的物体（例如静止物体的轮廓）上，而不是主要物体上。从技术上讲，你会失去焦点，但这没关系；移动的火光会模糊边缘并软化它所照亮的物体的阴影，所以你应该尽你所能来钉住硬边缘。

5.学会控制火焰的颜色

仔细观察火焰，您会看到多种颜色、梯度和强度，具体取决于温度、燃料类型、氧气量、氧气与燃料的混合程度等。

听起来很复杂，而且确实如此。但当谈到火焰摄影时，一些简单的技巧应该可以帮助您控制火焰的颜色 - 并获得您想要的照片。

看，在拍摄火焰时，最有影响力的因素是燃烧的燃料。木头、纸张、衣服或任何其他会释放出大量未燃烧颗粒（烟雾）的东西可能会燃烧成黄橙色。丁烷打火机、丙烷火炬、酒精含量高的液体或其他更容易与可用氧气混合的燃料会在蓝色一侧燃烧得更多。

蓝色和黄色不满足您吗？从不畏惧;您可以购买添加剂（准确地说是烟火着色剂）来随意改变火焰的颜色。我在当地的露营商店找到了一些预包装的粉末，它们效果很好。或者，如果您对化学感兴趣， 本文将介绍哪些化合物可用于创建哪些颜色。

您还有另一种选择：只需在后处理中更改火焰的颜色即可。由于火色占主导地位，因此可以轻松选择颜色并在整个图像中进行调整。我使用后处理来实现这个有趣的绿色火焰：

6.享受拍摄烟雾的乐趣

烟雾看起来很酷，但除非您采取措施确保它出现在场景中，否则您可能最终会得到无烟照片（或完全平淡无奇的烟雾照片，这几乎同样令人沮丧）。

您可以执行以下三件事来突出烟雾并捕捉华丽的效果：

  1. 确保你的火正在冒烟。高效燃烧的燃料（如一些燃气火炬和酒精）可能根本不会排放太多烟雾。使用木材或纸张等低效燃料来最大限度地提高烟雾输出量。
  2. 点燃烟雾。光源照射到烟雾中可以使这些线条凝固并帮助它们脱颖而出。使用逆光可以营造出最强烈的效果，而侧光则更适合营造神秘的外观。
  3. 使用较快的快门速度来冻结烟雾轨迹（从 1/100 秒开始，但如有必要，请增加此值）。较慢的快门速度会使烟雾看起来像薄雾，而不是清晰的缕缕。

另外，一定要拍摄大量图像。烟雾不断改变形状和方向，因此通常不足以捕捉到一个镜头并收工；相反，拍摄几十张照片，删除平庸的照片，并保持最好的状态。

7.从蜡烛开始

如果您想开始拍摄火焰，但还没有准备好先潜入水中，我建议您拍摄蜡烛。

蜡烛简单、相对安全且易于使用 - 因此您可以在没有任何高风险构图的情况下进行大量拍摄。

为了练习，尝试完成我上面讨论的三种主要类型的射击（射击作为主题，射击作为强调，射击作为光源）。

然后进行一些有趣的实验。当您继续操作时，请务必记下您的设置。特别是，确定冻结火焰所需的快门速度，以及照亮桌子上的拍摄对象所需的快门速度。最后，使用人造光源在单帧中拍摄火焰和周围环境。

如果您购物预算有限，那么购买二手相机装备是个好主意。

现代数码相机会定期更新，因此二手市场上充满了寻找新家的相机。二手相机是在不花太多钱的情况下升级装备的好方法（而且它们通常也物超所值）。

但在查看二手装备时，并非所有装备都符合标准。并非每个人都关心自己的装备，因此您必须谨慎行事。

以下是一些建议，可确保您在购买二手装备时获得最大的收益。这样，您就可以以原价的一小部分更新您的相机、镜头和配件！

购买二手相机

相机是复杂的机器，因此在购买二手机身时需要注意一些关键指标。

快门数

相机的快门次数就是快门在其使用寿命内被触发的次数。

（快门计数也称为快门启动次数。）

一般来说，快门计数可以很好地表明相机的使用量，类似于检查汽车的行驶里程。相机根据快门耐用性进行评级，发烧友型号的额定拍摄次数通常约为 150,000 张，专业型号的额定拍摄次数为 300,000 张或更高。

浏览时，低快门次数通常表示使用频率较低的项目。 2-5年相机的拍摄次数少于10,000张是非常低的，正常数量在30,000-50,000张左右。

如果相机的计数非常高，达到 100,000 或更多，那么最好避免使用它，特别是因为这个数字还可以让您稍微了解所有者对相机的使用情况。较高计数的相机可能用于专业用途（以及更艰苦的生活），而较低计数则表明休闲消费者使用。

那么如何知道相机的快门次数呢？

二手相机出售时通常会提供该编号。但如果您不确定，可以根据型号通过多种方式找到答案。查看这篇文章以获取指导： 查找相机当前的快门动作。

相机检查

在查看二手相机时，您可以检查一些事项以更好地了解其状况。

首先，取下机身盖，检查反光镜、对焦屏和镜头触点周围的相机内部。寻找这些区域是否有任何损坏、油污或粘稠物的迹象。

油污可能表明内部部件的机械装置无法正常工作，有时是由于相机受到碰撞或跌落所致。检查内部侧面周围是否有油迹。一个小手电筒在这里可以发挥很大的作用。

请记住尽可能正面朝下握住相机，以减少灰尘和污垢污染的风险。

如果您手头有镜头，则值得进行一次测试以查找传感器是否存在任何问题。

将相机设置为 f/16 至 f/22，将其对准明亮的拍摄对象（白墙或天空），然后拍摄一张照片。回放图像并放大 LCD 屏幕以查找任何痕迹和划痕。

灰尘点并不是一个大问题，因为简单的传感器清洁就可以解决它们。但线条可能是传感器上划痕的证据（这意味着最好避免使用相机）。

一般磨损

当然，寻找任何外部损坏迹象也很重要。轻微的划痕、磨损和痕迹是正常的，但严重的瑕疵则可能表明相机曾跌落过。橡胶握把经常会因频繁使用而开始脱落，但可以以较低的成本进行更换。

购买二手镜片

相机镜头价格昂贵，因此二手镜头是购买新镜头的绝佳选择。

然而，购买时需要注意一些事项。

镜片瑕疵

检查镜头时，您需要检查外部和内部光学器件。

从外部看，检查玻璃上是否有划痕或缺口。将镜头向光线倾斜可以帮助您确保光学器件处于良好状态。

请注意，即使镜头具有前置滤镜，其光学效果也可能并不完美。因此，拧下过滤器并检查真正的前部滤芯以确保其正确。

通常，镜头的对焦环或变焦环以及外镜筒会出现磨损迹象。简单的摩擦是正常的，通常不必担心。

继续，检查内部是否有灰尘和霉菌。用小灯照射镜头内并寻找任何颗粒。大多数镜头都会有小灰尘点，但请注意是否有大的斑点或看似污迹的区域，因为这些区域将表明镜头是否有任何起雾或其他内部问题。

光圈叶片

在镜头的后部，您会发现一个小控制杆，您可以推动它来打开光圈叶片。这样做，并检查刀片是否灵活且没有任何粘性，这可能是收集油的迹象。

在虹膜完全打开的情况下通过镜头观察，再次检查是否有任何颗粒或油斑。

清晰度

使用测试卡检查镜头清晰度。这些图案图表很容易在网上找到，它们可以贴在墙上并用于快速评估镜头。

它的工作原理如下：

将镜头安装到相机上，然后将相机放在三脚架上。将注意力集中在测试图上，然后使用遥控释放或自拍定时器启动相机（以确保不会造成任何相机抖动）。

检查相机液晶显示屏上的照片（或者，如果可以的话，在计算机上）。放大到 100% 以确保对焦。当然，某些相机和镜头需要在相机内进行精细调整才能达到完美，但任何极度不清晰的测试都可能表明镜头已掉落或未对准。

测试整个光圈范围并寻找边缘到边缘的清晰度也是一个好主意。即使在 f/2.8 下，测试图像的中心也应该相对清晰。

此外，在执行这些测试时，最好检查是否有任何外部痕迹或瑕疵，转动对焦环和变焦环以检查是否有任何粘性或刺耳的声音。

完成这些检查后，您将可以很好地了解镜头是否符合要求（并且值得购买！）。

哪里可以购买二手相机装备

如果您正在努力寻找高质量的二手相机装备，这里有一些建议：

相机店

许多相机零售商提供一些二手库存以及新相机。从经销商处购买有其优点，因为物品在添加到库存之前通常会经过检查，而且在出售之前通常会进行维修。

此外，大多数经销商都会有退货政策，因此如果您发现任何故障，您可以更换二手装备以获得全额退款。许多较好的经销商为二手装备提供三个月到一年的保修，这会让您在购买时高枕无忧。

当然，从经销商处购买的缺点之一是价格上涨。从专卖店购买的二手套件通常比从私人卖家购买的装备贵——因此您必须决定是否值得让您安心！

eBay 和私人卖家

直接从私人卖家那里购买是找到便宜货的最佳机会。有些人以远低于市场价格的价格出售他们的装备。如果您知道要寻找什么，并且对所售商品的质量和真实性充满信心，那么您通常可以获得超值优惠。

不过，购买二手相机装备时要小心谨慎。对任何看起来好得令人难以置信的交易，或者只接受当面现金的买家保持怀疑。使用 PayPal 或 PayPal 替代方案可提供额外的一层保护（这在在线销售中非常重要）。

当然，私人卖家通常不会提供保修，但为了讨价还价，你需要冒一定的风险。

购买二手相机装备：结论

购买二手相机装备就是要花时间寻找便宜货。仔细研究您正在考虑的二手装备，无论是来自经销商还是私人卖家，并留意明显的损坏迹象。

假设您在购买前仔细考虑并进行彻底检查，那么二手市场是一种以购买新装备成本一小部分的价格换购装备的绝佳方式。

反过来，这又可以让您有钱购买额外的套件 - 或者更好的是，您可以在一两次旅行中使用它！

摄影中的空间法则是什么？

摄影中的空间规则是一种结合视觉缺席的方法，为拍摄对象提供呼吸的空间。

虽然空间规则更像是一个指南而不是严格的规则，但它是一种方便的构图手段。这是为照片添加广阔感、 深度感和/或动感感的好方法。

为什么空间规则很重要？

要了解空间的规律，我们首先需要简单了解一下正空间和负空间。

摄影师使用正空间和负空间这两个术语来对比照片中具有影响力和更微妙的区域。

一般来说，积极空间是指吸引观众注意力的特定主题。另一方面，负空间对视觉的要求较低，并为图像中的主要事件提供了框架。

一般来说，空间规则决定了图像中负空间的使用。通过了解空间规则的本质，摄影师可以利用拍摄对象的意图，并增加图像的深度和视角。

空间规则很重要，因为它可以帮助摄影师阐明照片的能量，并且通过塑造关键视觉事件并为拍摄对象提供更多移动空间来引导观看者的眼睛。

使用空间规则：基础知识

要遵循摄影中的空间规则，首先要考虑拍摄对象的行为。

问问自己：拍摄对象在做什么？它是移动的还是静止的？它如何占据空间？

同时，想象一下你想在照片中传达的信息。是运动吗？看法？深度？叙述？

你的主题的性质和行为加上你的意图应该共同决定你如何应用空间规则。

看法

空间规则影响照片的主要方式之一是透视。拍摄对象周围的充足空间可以使拍摄对象显得更小或更大，具体取决于相机角度。

传递动力

摄影中的空间规则可以帮助您创造运动的印象。

为了传达动作，该规则建议在主题的前面或后面（或两者）都应留有空间。

例如，如果拍摄对象在场景中移动，您可以同时捕捉拍摄对象和拍摄对象周围的负空间。额外的空间传达了拍摄对象的运动，增加了紧作物可能缺乏的动力。

增加深度

摄影中的空间规则不仅限于高度活跃的主体；它也适用于固定主题！

例如，在肖像画中，您的构图可以通过将拍摄对象的凝视或手势与负空间配对来控制。拍摄对象的目光自然会引导我们的注意力——我们想看到拍摄对象看到的东西。

但当凝视遇到负空间时，观看者的眼睛往往会自然地回到凝视的原始来源。空间规则提供了一种增加深度和引导观众注意力的有机方式。

您还可以根据非人类/动物主题的运动、感知的手势和延伸来使用空间规则。通过跟踪非人类主体的动量、构图或行为，您将找到负空间的理想位置。

空间规则挑战

将空间规则应用于照片的过程本身并不困难。然而，在每张图像中塞满尽可能多的视觉信息的倾向可能会妨碍探索负空间。

相反，有意识地、谨慎地采取极简主义的方法。您还可以缩小或从主题上退后几步，以重新关注空间规则。

运用空间规则的技巧和技巧

以下是使用空间规则的一些技巧：

提示 1：也使用其他构图规则

将空间规则应用于摄影并不一定要以牺牲其他构图规则为代价。

事实上，将构图原则与摄影中的空间规则相结合可以增加创作成功照片的机会。

三分法、 引导线、 景深和重复等构图规则都可以与空间规则结合使用，以创造引人入胜的图像。

秘诀2：让它呼吸

空间的规则就是给一个主题或场景一个呼吸的空间。

因此，退后一步，缩小镜头，甚至尝试使用更广角的镜头；这样，您就可以为照片增添宽敞感。

提示 3：尝试不同的相机设置

您选择的相机设置可以帮助您更有效地遵循空间规则。

例如，您可以使用浅景深来用负空间包围拍摄对象。您还可以尝试使用较慢的快门速度并平移相机，同时在拍摄对象之前或之后留出空间以放大运动。

摄影中的空间规则：结论

空间规则旨在创造正负空间的和谐。

通过应用此规则，您可以强调并构建积极的主题，同时在图像中产生令人回味的重量和失重平衡。

空间规则常见问题解答

空间法则是什么？

在视觉艺术中，空间规则指导您在图像中包含负空间。

什么是负空间？

一般来说，负空间是指照片中未被主要主题占据的区域。通常，负空间作为框架来强调图像中的关键主题。

摄影师如何运用空间法则进行构图？

该规则鼓励摄影师利用负空间。有很多方法可以做到这一点。您可以通过选择极简背景来专注于将拍摄对象与负空间结合起来，也可以将肖像拍摄对象的目光与额外的负空间配对。

有哪些摄影师运用了空间法则？

利用空间法则的摄影师不计其数。例如，摄影师Martin Parr和Helen Levitt以及Hiroshi Sugimoto 、 Michael Kenna和Eric Kim就充分利用了这条规则。

什么时候才能打破摄影中的空间规则？

摄影就是发展个人的创作本能和方法。这就是为什么组合规则可以被打破。摄影中的空间规则只是一个指南——因此，如果图像在没有额外空间的情况下看起来更好，那么就跟随你的直觉吧。如果您不确定，请尝试使用不同的空间方法拍摄一系列照片并分析结果。

因此，深呼吸，让肺部充满树木产生的氧气，并了解如何拍摄令人惊叹的照片！

1. 找到一棵独立的树

田野中的一棵孤树照片是自然摄影的经典之作，理由很充分：你有一个强大的主要拍摄对象，你有一个美丽的背景，而且你经常可以在美丽的天空下拍摄这棵树。

请注意，您需要在构图中仔细放置这棵孤树。如果树是对称的，那么将它轻轻地放在框架中间就可以了。否则，您需要考虑三分法，它鼓励您将树放入框架的三分之一处。

如果您可以靠近，请尝试使用广角镜头来展示整棵树的所有辉煌。您还可以缩小以创建有趣的简约图像（树被美丽的背景框住）。

如果您无法靠近树，请考虑使用长焦镜头。您会得到更压缩的外观，但这不一定是坏事（它也可以帮助您模糊背景）。

因此，下次开车时，请环顾四周寻找潜在的拍摄对象。 Make sure you check out the background, too, as you don't want the viewer to be distracted by elements positioned off in the distance.

2. Look for tree tunnels

This is another classic tree photo: The tree tunnel, which features two rows of trees leading off into the distance:

Here, it's important that you find two unbroken, symmetrical rows of trees. You need a strong leading line in the center, and the tighter the tree lines, the better.

You can experiment with different depth of field approaches for creative images. A deep depth of field will show lots of detail, while a narrow depth of field has the potential to create highly artistic images.

If you can, include a person or two in the background; that way, the viewer has an obvious place to rest their eyes.

The tough part is actually finding the tree tunnel. I'd recommend doing some Googling for “tree tunnels,” “fall foliage walks,” and the like. You might also check out Instagram; see if you come across any great tree tunnel images taken in nearby areas.

Speaking of which: If you can shoot during the fall – when the colors are looking amazing – or even in the winter when the snow is falling, your results will be truly legendary.

3. Photograph the same tree for a year

Trees change over the course of the year, which gives you a fantastic tree time-lapse opportunity. This works best away from the equator, but you can try it pretty much anywhere (if you're working in the tropics, the changes will be more subtle).

First, find a tree and carefully determine your composition. I recommend using a tripod to maintain consistency; take photos of the exact position of the tripod and its height, then store them on your phone so you can easily reference them when you come back.

(If you can't pick a single composition, feel free to come up with three or four. But you'll need to carefully document each setup so you can return later on.)

Next, determine your settings . Make sure to record the aperture so you can keep the depth of field consistent. And if you're using a zoom lens, record the focal length.

Finally, take the same shot several times over the next twelve months! You can come back once during each season, or – if you want to create a more intensive time-lapse series – come back every month or even every week.

Once the cycle is complete, you'll have a beautiful set of images documenting the changing seasons.

4. Try some creative techniques

If your tree images are looking a bit bland , then why not try out a fun creative technique?

For instance, you might capture a:

  • Tree silhouette. This works great with trees featuring beautifully shaped branches! Head out around sunset, make sure your tree is framed against the bright sky, and expose for the brightest part of the scene.
  • Refraction shot . Bring along a lensball , hold it up in front of the tree, and shoot through the glass. You'll get an interesting inverted image inside the small glass sphere (see the example below).
  • Infrared scene . Go shooting on a sunny summer day with some clouds in the sky. Find a tree with plenty of green leaves, and use either an infrared filter or an IR-converted camera. You may need to experiment with the settings, but you'll end up with a beautiful dreamscape shot.
  • Long-exposure photo . If you can find a tree near a river or framed against a partly cloudy sky, you can create a beautiful long-exposure blur. Slow down your shutter speed (you may need a neutral density filter ), use a tripod, then photograph the tree surrounded by movement.

5. Focus on the details

Compositions that include the entire tree are nice…

…but tree detail images can be beautiful, too! In fact, trees offer all kinds of potential for amazing detail shots. Here are some items to consider:

  • Leaves. You can focus on a single leaf and widen the aperture for a beautiful bokeh background . Or you can grab a macro lens and focus even closer (so you highlight the leaf's veins).
  • Bark. Trees offer beautifully textured bark, so get up close and use a deep depth of field for plenty of detail. For maximum texture, position yourself so the bark is sidelit.
  • The trunk. Observe the root system around the trunk. See what patterns you can photograph at the foot of the tree.
  • Branches. Take a minute to look up . Interlocking branches can create beautiful patterns, especially when they're silhouetted against a bright sky.

6. Use trees as portrait backgrounds

Not every tree image needs to use the tree as the main subject; you can also use trees as stunning backgrounds.

Portrait photos, in particular, benefit from tree backdrops. You can use tree tunnels to frame your subject, or you can position a lone subject near a lone tree for a minimalistic effect.

Plus, in summer and fall, tree leaves make gorgeous background bokeh. Just put your subject in front of a leafy tree, widen the aperture, and watch as you create jaw-dropping portraits! This approach works especially well if you shoot during the golden hours and the background leaves are lit by the setting sun.

7. Try different vantage points

Most photographers shoot trees from the most obvious angle: Standing and looking straight ahead.

But if you want unique tree photos, why not mix it up a little? Here are a few fun perspectives you can use for more original tree images:

  • Low angle. Get down low and shoot from the perspective of a four-legged creature. This will create an intimate image that emphasizes the height of the surrounding trees. You might consider adding in a foreground subject; try placing flowers in the foreground while keeping the tree in the background.
  • Worm's-eye view. Get down low on the forest floor, but instead of pointing the lens straight ahead, point it up at the treetops. See if you can shoot from the middle of a clearing with a wide-angle lens; that way, the trees will seem to be reaching for the sky.
  • Bird's-eye view. For this angle – looking down from above – you'll need a drone, a helicopter, or some other way of getting high above the trees. It might take some work (and money), but the results can be spectacular!

8. Include wildlife in your tree photos

Do you like to photograph mammals, birds, or insects? Try combining the wildlife with the trees for spectacular forest images.

You can start small. Grab a close-focusing lens, then see if you can find some ants, beetles, caterpillars, or butterflies to capture.

And if you have a telephoto lens, try creating some portraits of the local wildlife. Depending on your location, squirrels, chipmunks, and even monkeys will make stunning subjects.

Want to photograph birds? You can, though unless you're shooting near a feeder or working in a blind, you'll need a very long lens. I'd recommend 300mm as an absolute minimum, but 400mm, 500mm, or even 600mm is ideal.

Tree photography: final words

Trees make amazing subjects, plus they're everywhere!

So remember these tree photography tips. Then head out with your camera and have fun. You're bound to capture some stunning photos!

The post 12 Must-Know Camera Settings for Concert Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Matthias Hombauer .

Struggling to determine the right concert photography settings for beautiful images of musicians, bands, and even symphonies? You've come to the right place.

Selecting the perfect camera settings is a key part of capturing awesome concert photos, especially in low-light situations. If you get your settings right, the results will be spectacular: crisp, clear, and full of detail. But if you get them wrong? Your images will look blurry, unpleasant, and just all-around bad.

That's why, in this article, I'm going to share 12 settings for concert photography. These are the exact camera settings I use in my own concert shooting, so you know they work. (And I promise: They'll help you boost your images and your career!)

Let's dive right in.

The best concert photography settings, in brief

Before we dive into the nitty-gritty, let's take a moment to review my go-to settings for concert photography. If you're eager to grab your camera and head to a gig tonight, these settings will net you solid results:

  • RAW format
  • 手动模式
  • A wide aperture
  • A reasonably fast shutter speed
  • A high ISO
  • Image stabilization
  • Auto White Balance
  • Spot metering
  • Back-button AF
  • Burst mode

Think of this list as your concert photography cheat sheet. It'll get you about 80% of the way – but to truly shine in this challenging field, you need to understand when to fine-tune your settings, you'll need to understand why these settings are so crucial and what they actually do , and you'll also need to learn a few additional camera settings to consider.

Also, always remember that every concert is unique. Lighting conditions can change from one moment to the next, and what works for a high-energy rock concert may not be ideal for a subdued jazz performance. Still, by dialing in these key settings, you'll be well on your way to capturing stellar images that bring the stage to life.

The 12 concert photography settings everyone should know

Looking to level up your photos of rock concerts, symphonies, and everything in between? Here are the settings that I recommend you keep in mind while photographing:

1. Shoot in RAW format

Here's your first concert photography setting, and it's a big one:

Always, always, always shoot in RAW.

If you shoot in JPEG, your camera will automatically add processing, such as contrast, saturation, and sharpness. And while it might look nice, it'll limit your post-production freedom, so you won't be able to further enhance your concert photos.

On the other hand, if you shoot in RAW, the camera won't process your photo at all. That way, you can change parameters such as exposure, white balance, saturation, contrast, and clarity long after you hit the shutter button.

(In other words: If you're careful and deliberate with your editing, you can make your photos look a lot better!)

2. Use Manual or Aperture Priority mode

When I started off doing concert photography, I used Aperture Priority mode . I would dial in the aperture, my camera would set the shutter speed accordingly, and I'd hit the shutter button.

And in general, Aperture Priority works well. It's great for beginners because it partially automates the exposure process, giving you one less thing to worry about.

But after shooting for a while, I recognized that only Manual mode would give me the flexibility I was after. I wanted to set the aperture, shutter speed, and ISO – and then change each setting on the fly based on my requirements.

So depending on your level of experience and comfort, pick one of these two options. Starting with Aperture Priority and working up to Manual can make sense, though if you're already familiar with Manual mode, you might test it out and see if you can use it effectively right away.

Pro tip: If you do choose Manual mode, make sure to frequently check your histogram to ensure your exposure is correct!

3. Use your lens's widest aperture setting

Struggling to decide which lens to use for concert photography? I always give the same advice: Use fast lenses and shoot them wide open.

Set your aperture to the smallest f-number your lens allows, which will give you the biggest aperture opening. That way, the most possible light hits your sensor.

A wide aperture is especially important in low-light concert photography. If possible, shoot with an f/2.8, f/1.8, f/1.4, or f/1.2 lens.

If you're a beginner on a budget, I'd recommend grabbing a 50mm f/1.8 lens , which is cheap, features a wide maximum aperture, and offers surprisingly nice image quality.

4. Use a fast shutter speed

Have you ever been to a concert where the artist was running and jumping from one side of the stage to the other?

This type of action makes for some great photography – but to freeze such movement, you must use a fast shutter speed.

In general, I set my shutter speed to 1/200s or faster (and depending on the level of action, you may want to push this even higher.) Certain concerts will allow you to get away with a slower speed, such as 1/160s, but it's often better to err on the side of caution and go higher rather than lower, even if you're forced to increase your ISO as a result. Speaking of which:

5. Boost your ISO

The higher your ISO, the less light you need for a proper exposure – and in concert photography, where light is generally limited, this is a key setting to get right.

Your camera's ISO range likely starts at 100. But if you're shooting a low-light concert, I'd recommend kicking this up to 1600, 3200, or even 6400. Otherwise, your shots will end up far too dark (or you'll be forced to drop your shutter speed, which will introduce blur).

Unfortunately, a high ISO does come with a significant tradeoff: image noise.

In other words, as you push your ISO from 400 to 800 to 1600, you start to get little flecks of color and light that look pretty bad. The specifics will depend on your camera (modern sensors do a very good job of minimizing high-ISO noise!), but you should always be cautious when boosting the ISO. Only raise it when absolutely necessary, and be mindful of your particular camera's high-ISO capabilities.

It can help to spend some time capturing test shots at various ISOs, then magnifying the images on your computer and evaluating the noise levels in your images. Also note that you can sometimes salvage noise-heavy images with noise reduction during post-processing, or you can convert your files to black and white for a grittier, noir-type look.

6. Turn on image stabilization

Modern camera gear offers a lot of tech to make our lives easier, and image stabilization is one of those wonderful advancements. Available in many of today's lenses and some (mostly high-end) mirrorless cameras, image stabilization helps to counteract the effects of camera shake so you can keep your files looking tack-sharp.

Imagine you're at a concert and trying to shoot in low-light conditions. If your hands shake, you shoot while panning, or you get bumped by an audience member or another photographer, you risk introducing blur into your images, even if you're working at a reasonably fast shutter speed.

Turn on your camera or lens's image stabilization, however, and it'll compensate for minor camera movements. In fact, it can make a noticeable difference in the sharpness of your photos, and it'll certainly improve your consistency.

Not sure whether your camera or lens offers image stabilization? This feature can be labeled differently depending on your gear. For instance, camera-based image stabilization is often referred to as IBIS (in-body image stabilization), while lens-based image stabilization goes by a host of acronyms like IS, VR, OS, OSS, or VC. When in doubt, do a bit of Googling!

Pro tip: It's important to remember that while image stabilization can help with camera shake, it won't freeze the motion of a performer jumping around the stage. For that, you'll still need a fast shutter speed!

7. Use spot metering

Spot metering limits your camera's exposure readings to the center of the scene – which allows you to determine the exposure based on a small subject (eg, a face). It works especially well when your subject and background are differently lit.

When shooting concerts, the artist will often be lit by a spotlight while the rest of the stage remains dark. So here's what you do:

First, switch your camera to spot metering mode.

Then place the artist's face in the middle of your viewfinder and memorize the recommended exposure settings.

If you're using Manual mode, you can dial in the settings, then compose without worrying about fluctuating meter readings. If you're using Aperture Priority, you'll need to lock the exposure; that way, you don't end up with varied exposures as the performers jump around the frame.

If you don't like spot metering and it's giving you bad results, you can try your camera's matrix/evaluative metering mode. The camera will take a light reading at several points in the scene, and this can work – but you'll want to be on the lookout for overexposed faces, especially when the background is dark.

8. Use the middle autofocus point

Did you know that different autofocus points feature different levels of accuracy?

这是真的。 Peripheral autofocus points tend to work fine in good light, but the performance weakens as the light drops. Whereas the center autofocus point remains effective in both good light and bad.

That's why I recommend you use the central focus point in low-light situations. It'll be the most accurate, and it'll ensure you get the sharpest results, no matter what the artist is doing on stage.

If you don't want the artist to sit smack-dab in the center of the frame, you'll need to use a focus-and-recompose technique; simply push your shutter button halfway down to focus on the artist's face – this will lock focus – then adjust your composition until you get the desired framing. Once you've nailed both focus and composition, press the shutter button the rest of the way.

Note: To use this focus-and-recompose technique, you'll need to set your camera to One-Shot AF , also known as AF-S. Otherwise, the camera will focus continuously while you reframe your picture.

(You can also set up back-button focus , which many shooters – myself included! – love. With back-button AF, you use a button on the rear of your camera to lock focus, then use the shutter button to take the shot.)

9. Use Auto White Balance

White balance combats unwanted color casts in your scene, and it's important to use if you want good-looking photos.

However, I highly recommend you deal with white balance after taking your photos, during post-processing. So set your camera to Auto White Balance , then ignore the WB setting until you're back at home.

You see, if you shoot in RAW , the white balance is completely flexible. Whether you determine the white balance setting at the time of capture or whether you wait until you've opened up Lightroom days later makes zero difference.

Plus, setting the white balance during a concert is difficult to do, especially when you have different lights flashing all around the stage. So do yourself a favor and leave the white balance setting for another time!

10. Use burst mode

Your camera's burst mode setting , also referred to as continuous shooting, lets you do rapid-fire photography. With burst mode activated, you can shoot five, ten, or even sixty frames per second, depending on your camera.

And this is hugely helpful in concert photography for two reasons:

  1. If you take several shots in a row, at least one of them will probably turn out sharp even if the others aren't in focus.
  2. Multiple photos increase your chances of nailing the perfect frame.

Now, I don't recommend you set your camera to its high-speed continuous shooting mode and use it nonstop. You'll run out of storage space pretty quickly, plus you'll just end up with thousands of unnecessary photos.

But I do recommend analyzing the situation, then – when you're ready to capture split-second action shots – turn on burst mode and use it judiciously. Of course, be sure to stock up on memory cards, and be prepared to spend some extra time going through your files when you get home. Even a careful burst-mode shooter will end up with a lot of files at the end of a night, and while you'll likely end up with some absolute gems, storing and finding them can require real effort.

11. Never use flash

This is a quick tip but an important one: Don't use flash at a concert.

First, you're not allowed; imagine ten photographers bursting their flashes all at the same time – it'd distract the audience and the musicians.

And straight-flash pictures don't look great. For good flash photography, you'll generally need to position your flash off to the side of the artist (ie, you'll need an off-camera flash), which isn't really feasible in a concert setting.

So turn off that flash and rely on careful concert photography settings, such as a high ISO and a wide aperture, for well-exposed files.

12. Consider using a silent shooting mode

Concert photography can be enthralling. But while you're absorbed in capturing the event, the noise of your camera's shutter can be a distraction for those around you – and you might not even realize it!

This is where your camera's silent mode can come in handy. You see, many mirrorless cameras, and even some DSLRs, offer silent-shooting options; these are designed for quieter events like weddings and award ceremonies, where it's essential that the photographer remains as inconspicuous as possible. Turn on silent shooting, and the chatter of your camera will instantly disappear.

Not all concerts require a quiet camera, of course. A heavy-metal band, for instance, will drown out the sound of your camera shutter – but in settings like low-key acoustic concerts or classical performances, the quiet or silent mode can make a huge difference. That way, you can click away without drawing attention, and both the audience and the performers will thank you.

Plus, some cameras offer increased continuous shooting speeds when set to their silent-shooting mode, which allows you to capture more frames in quick succession!

Must-know concert photography settings: final words

Now that you've finished this article, you're well-equipped to capture some stunning concert photos! Whether you're a beginner or have been shooting concerts for a while, I hope you found these concert settings tips to be both practical and easy to apply.

So the next time you're out shooting a concert, make sure to dial in the settings I shared. Your photos will instantly improve!

应对明亮阳光的 5 个基本策略

所以你发现自己在户外，手里拿着相机，阳光灿烂。显然光线条件并不理想，但你能做什么呢？

您可以采取五种基本方法，每种方法都有自己的优点和缺点。这些策略的有效性取决于您的具体情况，因此最好熟悉所有这些策略并根据需要选择不同的技术。

1. 漫射光线

我们已经确定，明亮的阳光是一种硬光源，会产生深沉、戏剧性的阴影。解决这个问题的一种方法是在太阳和拍摄对象之间使用某种漫射材料。

The fabric will disperse the light over a broader area, effectively reducing those problematic shadows and toning down contrast.最终结果是更柔和、更自然的外观。

2.遮挡光线

扩散并不总是一种选择；也许您没有必要的设备，或者根本无法有效地定位它。在这种情况下，遮挡光线是您的下一个最佳选择。

本质上，你想要给你的拍摄对象遮荫。这并不意味着将它们推到树下，尽管这可能有效。但您也可以使用建筑物甚至大雨伞等物体来投射阴影，这有助于降低对比度并使拍摄对象上的光线更加均匀。

3.添加更多光线

如果您发现自然阳光在拍摄对象上投射出刺眼的阴影，为什么不添加自己的光源呢？这可能是机外闪光灯或将光线反射回拍摄对象的反射器。

当然，这有点棘手 - 在户外使用闪光灯可能会让人感到害怕，并且需要一些练习才能获得正确的平衡。但如果操作正确，这种技术可以帮助消除那些不讨人喜欢的阴影，让你的拍摄对象看起来更加平衡、令人愉悦。

4.等待灯光变化

如果您有足够的等待时间，这可能是一个很好的策略。云可以充当天然的漫射器，落日提供的光线更柔和，比中午的刺眼阳光更容易使用。

换句话说，云是你的朋友；它们柔化了光线，让您的工作变得更加轻松。日出和日落期间的大气层也有类似的效果，为您提供更柔和、更漫射的光线，通常更容易使用。

5.拥抱光明

最后但并非最不重要的一点是，为什么不迎接挑战呢？明亮的阳光会带来深阴影和高对比度，但这些不一定是坏事。您可以创造性地使用它们来制作引人注目的图像。

例如，鲜明的对比实际上可以为风景增添戏剧感或使肖像更有趣。这种方法就是实验，尝试高对比度的镜头，并简单地欣赏直射阳光如何以独特的方式渲染拍摄对象。

如何在明亮的阳光下拍出好照片：提示和技巧

在本节中，我提供了大量详细、实用的指南，用于拍摄肖像、街景、风景等——即使是在最刺眼的光线下！

1.使用弹出式扩散器

您可能主要将柔光罩与室内闪光摄影联系起来，但它们在户外环境中也非常有用。漫射器本质上是一块半透明材料，可以散射光线，软化那些刺眼的阴影并降低对比度。使用闪光灯时，您可以使用各种形式的柔光罩，从白色雨伞到柔光箱，但在户外工作时，标准片材或圆形弹出式柔光罩就可以了。

您或助手只需将漫射器放在灯光和拍摄对象之间，结果通常会呈现自然的照明效果。这种技术对于人像和特写摄影特别有用，但请记住柔光器确实有其局限性；您无法将其准确地放在建筑物或广阔的风景上！

2. 移至阴凉处

在阳光直射下拍摄美丽图像的最简单方法？

只要搬到阴凉处就可以了。

显然，与扩散器技术一样，这并不总是可行 - 您当然无法移动整个海景！ – 但对于某些主题，进入阴影是快速且容易的。假设您不受特定位置的限制，这是拍摄肖像时的一个很好的解决方案。

毕竟，有时最简单的解决方案是最好的！

3. 制作自己的灯罩

对于不可移动的小物体 - 例如田野中的一朵小花- 创建您自己的阴影！

您有几种不同的选择，其中一些比其他更方便：

  • 用身体挡住光线
  • 让助手站在拍摄对象和灯光之间
  • 在拍摄对象上方放一块纸板或一把雨伞

请注意，根据光线的方向，其中一些选项会更有效（例如，如果明亮的太阳位于头顶正上方，则很难用自己的身体遮挡它）。

4.使用补光闪光灯

在直射阳光下拍摄的最大问题之一是刺眼的阴影。例如，肖像拍摄对象的下巴下方会出现不需要的阴影，花朵的花瓣下方会出现较重的阴影，宠物的头部和身体下方会出现深色阴影。

一般来说，这些刺眼的阴影看起来很糟糕，但有一个简单的解决方案：

补闪。

只需将闪光灯对准黑暗阴影并开火即可！确保闪光灯处于低功率设置 - 毕竟，您不想让拍摄对象的底部比顶部更亮！ – 并尝试不同的闪光角度以获得最佳效果。

您还可以尝试将太阳放在拍摄对象的后面，然后使用补光闪光灯照亮拍摄对象的正面。它看起来确实不错，但要注意镜头眩光。

5.使用反光板

想要填充刺眼的阴影但不喜欢使用闪光灯？

您还有另一个简单的选择：

一个反光镜。

反射器是白色或金属物品，可将光线反射回较暗的区域，而且非常易于使用。只需将反光板指向您想要提亮的区域，然后调整它直到获得良好的填充（通过来回调整反光板的角度，您将看到反射光的位置变化，并且您可以使用此“预览”来微调效果）。

请注意，您也可以尝试我在上一节中提到的相同策略，将拍摄对象放置在太阳前面并将光线反射回其正面。反光罩的威力不如补光闪光灯，因此您需要仔细调整它的角度才能获得最大效果 - 但如果正确，结果将是惊人的。

6.改变你的观点

有时，将拍摄对象移动到阴影中是不可能的，但在拍摄对象周围移动可以产生相同的效果。

例如，如果您在森林中拍摄一棵有趣的树，您可能会移动到树的另一侧，您可能会发现树上被阴影笼罩的有趣部分，或者您可能会降低并向上拍摄。

这个想法是仔细观察你的拍摄对象，寻找最大化阴影并最小化明亮高光和恼人对比度的方法。

7.使用遮光罩

患有镜头眩光？

虽然耀斑可能很艺术，但它也可能非常烦人，尤其是当您追求干净、简单的图像时。

幸运的是，许多镜头都配有遮光罩，可以阻挡产生眩光的光线并保持您的照片无眩光。

如果您没有遮光罩，也不必担心；用纸板制作遮光罩或用手遮挡镜头免受阳光照射并不困难。

（只要确保你的临时镜头遮光罩和你的手远离镜头 - 否则，你将在后期制作中进行大量裁剪！）

8.考虑使用过滤器

不幸的是，滤镜并不能为明亮的阳光提供神奇的解决方案——没有“避免阳光直射”滤镜，至少目前还没有——但滤镜对于阳光直射摄影来说可以很方便。

例如， 偏光滤镜将有助于减少反射，此外，它还可以帮助您获得鲜艳的色彩（包括美丽的蓝天）。

中性密度滤镜将减少照射到相机传感器的光线，从而在中午降低快门速度并缩小光圈。

（为什么这可能有用？有时，您会想要使用大光圈拍摄以获得浅景深效果，或者您会想要慢速快门速度来传达运动模糊。）

9. 调整白平衡设置

如今，几乎所有数码相机都允许您在不同的白平衡设置之间进行选择（例如，您可以拨入白平衡预设，例如阴天或日光，或者您可以根据场景设置自定义白平衡）。

现在，假设您以 RAW 格式拍摄，您可以稍后在后期处理中调整白平衡。但如果您以 JPEG 格式拍摄，或者您只是希望在相机内获得正确的效果，那么您需要从一开始就仔细设置白平衡。

这对于在明亮的阳光下拍摄好照片有何帮助？

那么，白平衡可以提供增强高光和阴影外观的艺术效果。例如，较冷的白平衡可以为更多单色图像带来整洁的效果，而暖白平衡将使明亮的阳光显得更柔和、更诱人。

10.使用点测光以获得最佳效果

刺眼的阳光使正确的测光变得困难。所以这是我的建议：

使用点测光。这将迫使您的相机根据场景的目标部分进行曝光；您可以瞄准主要拍摄对象，然后拨入建议的曝光设置。

或者，您可以在镜头中对中间色调进行测光——这将确保整个场景的曝光相对良好（与前一种技术相反，前一种技术将确保您对拍摄对象进行曝光）。

拍摄图像后，检查相机背面进行预览；您可能需要根据结果调整您的技术。在这里，您的直方图可以非常方便，特别是因为在明亮的阳光下很难准确评估 LCD 预览。

另外，如果您有充裕的时间，请尝试在拍摄多张照片时对场景的不同部分进行测光 - 这样您就可以稍后选择最佳选项。

11. 仔细选择一天中的拍摄时间

我们大多数人都没有办法整天坐着等待完美的光线。

但提前一两个小时出发或晚一两个小时出发可能是可行的——如果可以的话，我强烈建议您考虑这样做。

您看，一天中的时间会极大地影响您的拍摄。中午的光线令人不舒服、刺眼，但如果您在清晨或傍晚外出，即使是直射阳光也会看起来不错。您将失去不需要的对比度，您将失去丑陋的阴影，并且您将获得柔和的金色光线，使您的拍摄对象更加美丽。

合理？

13.拍摄剪影

俗话说：

如果你无法击败他们，那就加入他们吧！

这适用于在明亮的阳光下拍摄物体时。如果太阳给你带来了麻烦，那就利用它来为你带来好处；让您的拍摄对象站在明亮的光线前，然后全天捕捉令人惊叹的剪影。

我建议降低高度（这样你就可以在明亮的天空下拍摄）。构图时要确保主题在背景下清晰可见。

13. 使用对比

对比可能看起来像是你的敌人——但只要有一点创造力，它就可以成为你的盟友。考虑一下街头摄影领域，动态光影可以创造出引人注目的图像。放置得当的阴影可以为您的构图增添深度和趣味！

在肖像画中，部分阴影的脸部可以散发出神秘或喜怒无常的氛围。关键是要有意识地使用对比。虽然这种方法可能并不适合所有场合，但如果做得正确，它可以拍出真正迷人的照片。

14.黑白分明

如果您发现自己在过多的对比度和褪色的颜色中挣扎，为什么不考虑单色方法呢？黑白摄影在光与影之间的作用中蓬勃发展，使其成为处理明亮阳光时的有力选择。

您不必从一开始就致力于黑白，特别是如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄（而且您绝对应该这样做！）。只需捕获图像，然后在后期处理过程中将其转换为单色即可。您可能会发现高光和阴影实际上改善了您的构图！

如何在明亮的阳光下拍出好照片：最后的话

从利用漫射器和拥抱对比度，甚至冒险进入黑白世界，无论太阳的位置如何，都有一系列选项可帮助您捕捉令人惊叹的图像。

Let's get started.

最好的风景摄影装备

您可能认为您可以使用智能手机拍摄一些照片，您并非完全错误。智能手机已经取得了长足的进步，它们的相机可以拍出一些精彩的照片。但是，假设您想要更多：更多的控制、更多的细节以及创建与您正在捕捉的场景相符的大照片的能力。这就是专业风景摄影设备发挥作用的地方。投资合适的装备可以带来很大的改变。

可互换镜头相机

如果您认真对待风景类型，您会想要选择一台好的风景摄影相机，例如全画幅数码单反相机或无反光镜型号。例如，佳能 EOS R5或 索尼 a7R IV将提供大量的百万像素（用于制作大型照片）以及稳定的低光功能（用于天文摄影）。如果您的预算紧张，请考虑较旧的全画幅 DSLR（例如佳能 6D或尼康 D800 ）。请记住，传感器越大越好，但传感器较小的 APS-C 或微型三分之四相机肯定可以完成任务。

广角镜头

一旦您获得了一台好的相机，您就会想要拥有一些高质量的风景摄影镜头。广角镜头是一个很好的起点。广角镜头的美妙之处在于它可以捕捉到更多您面前的场景。如果您最初只能买一个镜头，我通常建议使用广角到标准变焦镜头。对于那些刚刚开始摄影之旅的人来说，24-70mm f/4 镜头是一个不错的选择。

随着时间的推移，您可能会想要多元化。例如，70-200mm f/4 镜头可让您在不牺牲质量的情况下捕捉更亲密的风景场景。如果您正在寻找能够捕捉广阔远景的镜头，超广角 12-24mm f/4 镜头是完美的选择，尽管它可能有点贵。

三脚架

虽然我稍后会详细讨论相机设置，但重要的是要认识到大多数风景摄影都是在狭窄的光圈和光线较低的情况下进行的。当然可以实现曝光良好的照片，但通常只有将快门速度延长到 1/30 秒及以上才能实现。

如果你曾经尝试过以 1/30 秒的速度手持相机，你就会知道这真的很难；除非你的手非常稳定并且你的技术非常出色，否则你最终会得到无法使用的模糊图像。 （此外，即使是最稳定的摄影师也经常无法以一秒或更高的快门速度手持图像！）

这就是一个好的风景三脚架派上用场的地方。您可以使用它来稳定您的相机，并在 1 秒、5 秒甚至 30 秒的长时间曝光下保持照片清晰。是的，三脚架可能很昂贵，但最好的三脚架可以使用多年。将其视为对照片清晰度的投资！

顺便说一句：即使光线足够强，可以提供较快的快门速度，三脚架仍然很有用。它会迫使你放慢速度并更仔细地考虑你的构图。

一些过滤器

初学者常常忽视过滤器的重要性。在捕捉完美镜头的兴奋中，您很容易忘记有时您需要额外装备的帮助。圆偏振镜就是这样一种可以改变游戏规则的滤镜。当您拍摄水体时，它可以减少不必要的反射，并使秋季森林照片中的色彩更加流行。所以它是您装备中的必备品。

中性密度 (ND) 滤镜是另一组您会发现非常有价值的工具。这些滤镜减少了进入镜头的光线量，让您可以使用更长的快门速度。结果？无论是丝般光滑的水面还是纤细的云朵，都能拍出令人惊叹的长时间曝光照片。

然后需要考虑分级中性密度滤光片。它们可能有用，但不是必需的；您可以使用高动态范围 (HDR) 技术实现类似的效果。

关键配件

装备不仅仅停留在相机和镜头上。如果您徒步穿越大自然寻找独一无二的镜头，您将需要一些额外的东西来让您的生活更轻松。舒适、宽敞的背包是您的首要必备品。相信我，当您徒步数小时寻找完美地点时，一切都会变得不同。

风景摄影技巧

准备好学习如何将风景拍摄从零变成英雄了吗？在本节中，我将提供有关如何使用光线、创作令人惊叹的构图等等的最佳技巧。

1. 提前勘察潜在地点

把风景摄影想象成一顿精心准备的饭菜。侦察是您在实际烹饪开始之前所做的准备工作。相信我，捕捉千载难逢的镜头的关键通常涉及大量的准备工作，就像在厨房一样。侦察的重要性怎么强调都不为过。有时，你只要出现就可以得到幸运的机会，但大多数时候，神奇的事情发生是因为你知道在哪里以及何时出现。

首先在网上甚至通过老式地形图研究潜在的位置。只要有可能，请提前访问您选择的地点。这可能是在实际拍摄前几天、几周甚至几个小时。查看景观的几何形状，并想象不同的元素如何融入框架中。照明是另一个需要考虑的重要方面。显示太阳轨迹的应用程序可能是无价的工具。了解光线落在哪里可以帮助您预测拍摄对象在不同照明条件下的外观。因此，无论是著名的旅游景点还是国家公园的未开发角落，都请给自己充足的时间去探索。你的作品集会因此而感谢你。

2.寻找焦点

一旦掌握了设置，就可以开始考虑风景摄影构图（即场景中元素的排列）。

虽然构图可能是一个复杂的主题，但我可以提供一些基本指南，这些指南将对您的照片产生巨大的影响。

首先，几乎每一张精彩的风景照片都需要某种焦点——一个吸引眼球并吸引观众注意力的主要主题。

根据我的经验，一张没有焦点的风景照片最终看起来相当平淡和空洞。另外，它会让观看者的眼睛在图像中徘徊，无处休息。

请注意，焦点可以采取多种形式，包括：

  • 建筑物和构筑物（如上图所示）
  • 引人注目的树木
  • 巨石或岩层
  • 野生动物剪影
  • 一个人

然后，一旦确定了风景照片的焦点，请仔细考虑将其放置在画面中的位置。 Try to go beyond a conventional “centered” composition (with the main subject sitting statically in the middle of the shot). Instead, try using the rule of thirds , or go for a minimalist composition by placing the focal point off to the side.

3. Include a stunning foreground

Beginner landscape photographers tend to find a beautiful scene, point their camera, and then hit the shutter button.

And while the resulting shots look nice, they're often missing something powerful:

An eye-catching foreground , one that immediately captures the viewer's attention and helps lead them into the scene. (A good foreground can also make the scene appear more three-dimensional, which is almost always a good thing!)

Good foregrounds tend to feature beautiful details, such as flowers, patches of foliage, water moving through a stream, glistening rocks, or waves lapping up on the sand. This next image, for example, uses a field full of flowers to add foreground interest:

Note that you'll generally need a wide-angle lens to pull this off. The wider the field of view, the easier it'll be to include both a beautiful foreground and a stunning background.合理？

4. Don't forget about the sky

In landscape photography, you should always, always, always think about the sky .

Clear skies, for instance, tend to look bland and lifeless, while a mix of clouds and sun offers all sorts of interest (and explosive colors at sunrise and sunset!).

I like to check the weather forecast before planning my landscape photography outings; that way, I can head out on partly cloudy days and maximize my time spent with beautiful skies.

Now, I'm not saying that you'll never capture great landscape photos on clear days. But if you're faced with a clear sky, consider waiting to see if you get a couple of clouds – or, if you don't have the time, try to subordinate the sky to the rest of the scene by placing it in the upper third of the image and contrasting it with a stunning foreground.

On the other hand, if the sky is filled with drama, interesting cloud formations, or colors, then let it shine. Place the horizon in the bottom third of the frame to emphasize the heavens, like this:

Pro tip: If your skies aren't looking quite as intense as you'd like, consider enhancing them with filters. Neutral density filters will let you use long shutter speeds that stretch the clouds like cotton candy, while graduated neutral density filters will help you balance the sky and foreground exposure so you can capture plenty of detail.

5. Simplify your compositions

Have you ever looked at a landscape photo and felt overwhelmed? Maybe it's bursting with elements—trees, rocks, animals, and so on. But sometimes, less really is more. Focusing on minimal elements can amplify the visual impact of your shots.

Start by scanning your scene. What can you take away? Keep asking this question until you're left with just the core elements that make the scene special.

Now, consider framing your shot with an emphasis on shapes and lines rather than the actual subject. A tree becomes a vertical line, a lake turns into a flat plane. This abstraction helps you see the scene in terms of geometry, making it easier to frame a compelling shot.

What you're left with are landscape photos that almost feel like modern art pieces. The simplicity draws the viewer in, guiding their eyes effortlessly through the image. Trust me, this technique will lead to some of your most memorable captures.

6. Use leading lines to add dynamism

Leading lines are lines that encourage the eye through the image (generally toward the main subject; see above!).

And in landscape photography, a good leading line or two can be the difference between a mediocre snapshot and a great image.

(Why? Leading lines draw the viewer into the photo, plus they add lots of depth!)

Now, leading lines might seem hard to find, but they're actually pretty common. You just have to know where to look! For instance, you can create leading lines using:

  • Roads
  • Sand patterns
  • Receding waves
  • Rivers
  • Cracks in ice
  • Leaves
  • Fallen logs

Really, anything line-like can work. The trick is to position the lines in the foreground. Then use a wide-angle lens and get down low, so that the leading lines appear huge in the frame and immediately captivate the viewer:

7. Include human elements to add scale

Capturing the vastness of a landscape often poses a real challenge. Many times, a picture fails to convey the grandeur of a scene because there's nothing for scale. Here's a way around that: include something human for perspective.

想一想。 A road winding into the horizon under towering mountains suddenly brings those peaks into dramatic focus. You see that road, and you instantly know those mountains are gigantic.

Now, imagine photographing a solitary figure next to an awe-inspiring redwood. Instantly, you're not just looking at a tree; you're looking at a monument of nature. That person becomes a measuring stick for the tree's grandiosity.

Of course, whether you want to include human elements is entirely up to you! Some photographers might view this approach as muddying the purity of a natural scene, and if you feel the same, that's completely okay.

Additionally, keep in mind that balance is key. Human elements should complement, not distract. Don't include too much human content. Instead, integrate the artificial elements within the composition. When done right, the effect can be nothing short of spectacular.

8. Use color to your advantage

Thinking about colors in landscape photography isn't just about capturing a pretty sunset. Color management can make or break a photo, influencing the viewer's emotions and directing their eyes through the composition.

So, how can you leverage color to elevate your landscape shots? One effective approach is to use complementary colors. These are colors that sit opposite each other on the color wheel. Think of the classic duo of blue and orange. When you frame a sunlit canyon against a clear blue sky, these complementary colors can create a striking contrast that adds depth and excitement to your shot.

Another approach involves analogous colors, those that are adjacent on the color wheel. These can imbue your photos with a sense of harmony. Consider a woodland scene dappled with the golden light of the setting sun. The warm hues of yellow, orange, and red can create an inviting, peaceful atmosphere that draws viewers in.

And don't overlook the power of color to convey mood. Colors are more than just eye candy; they can serve as an emotional language. Imagine capturing a misty morning in the mountains. The cooler shades of blue and gray might evoke feelings of solitude or introspection.

You also have the option of limiting color to make a specific element stand out. For example, a field of green grass against a blue sky is visually appealing. But include a single, bright-red tulip, and suddenly you have a focal point that commands attention.

The most experienced landscape photographers are selective about the colors they include or exclude from a shot. A splash of unexpected color can captivate viewers, but remember that poorly managed colors can also distract. So, next time you're framing a shot, take a moment to think about the color composition. You might be surprised at how much of an impact it can make.

9. Capture movement with long-exposure techniques

When most people think about landscapes, they think of calm, serene, and passive environments. However, landscapes are rarely completely still – and if you can convey this movement, you'll add extra drama and moodiness to your images.

(Plus, you can use movement to create leading lines or to produce an eye-catching focal point.)

Here's what you do:

First, look for motion, even if it's subtle. Search for wind in the trees, waves on the beach, water flowing through a stream or over a waterfall, birds flying, or clouds moving overhead. Mount your camera on a tripod and compose your shot.

Second, lengthen your shutter speed to 1/30s and beyond, then set your exposure. Note that different shutter speeds will give you dramatically different results, so it's a good idea to take several shots while making adjustments. If you're working in bright conditions, consider using an ND filter or a polarizer to reduce the light hitting the sensor; that way, you can drop your shutter speed further without worrying about overexposure.

Note that landscape photographers achieve all kinds of different effects simply by experimenting with various shutter speeds. A 1/15s shot, for instance, will blur moving water but retain plenty of detail in the sky, like this:

Whereas a 30s shot will heavily blur the water and start to stretch the clouds.

At the end of the day, working with movement is a lot of fun. Just embrace the effect and see what you can create!

10. Photograph during the golden hour and blue hour

The golden hour is the time just before sunset and just after sunrise, when the sun is low in the sky and produces a beautiful, warm light.

And the golden hour is amazing for landscape photography. For one, the sun softly illuminates the scene, emphasizing all the little details. Look at how the golden light falls perfectly on these snow-covered trees:

The golden hour also offers lots of cotton-candy-colored skies, and the angle of the low sun creates interesting shadows while enhancing textures.

But the golden hour isn't the only time of day that's great for landscape photography. Light during the blue hour – that is, the time just before sunrise and just after sunset – can look amazing, too: soft, ethereal, cool, and magical. (Plus, due to the limited light, the blue hour is a great time to do long-exposure landscape shots !)

Now, you might be wondering:

Should I only photograph landscapes during the golden hour and the blue hour? Or is it okay to head out at other times, too?

这是个好问题。 In my experience, it's possible to get beautiful landscape photos on heavily overcast days, but you'll want to find the right subjects – such as foliage, forests , and waterfalls – and I'd recommend including very little of the sky in your composition.

As for midday landscape photography in bright sun: Avoid it whenever possible. Midday sun will cast unflattering shadows, wash out colors, and produce lots of unpleasant contrast.

11. Capture intimate landscape shots

Most landscape photos you see employ a wide-angle lens. And there's a good reason for it: wide-angle lenses capture sweeping vistas effectively. But sometimes, the real beauty lies in the details. Don't be afraid to get up close and personal with your landscape. This doesn't mean you should only use macro lenses to highlight the intricacies of leaves on a forest floor, though that's a valid approach.

Telephoto lenses can also be your best friends. These lenses let you zero in on specific elements, like interesting rock formations or a cluster of vibrant autumn trees. The result can be an image that feels more intimate, offering the viewer a unique point of view. The landscape is filled with overlooked treasures, from patterns in the mountains to the way light hits a bunch of leaves. By breaking away from the convention of wide-angle shooting, you can find beauty in unexpected places.

12. Test out creative landscape photo ideas

Landscape photography is immensely popular, and because of this, it can sometimes feel like every shot has been taken, every angle explored. But the creative possibilities are endless if you're willing to step out of the traditional box. Intentional camera movement, for instance, can produce a pleasing blur effect that's both dreamy and artistic. It's not the crystal-clear, hyper-detailed shot that's often prized in landscape photography, but the abstract results can be stunning in their own right.

Want more? Consider freelensing. This technique involves detaching the lens and holding it in front of the camera body, tilting it slightly to create a unique focus plane. This can add unexpected blurs and light leaks, offering a fresh take on a familiar landscape.

Don't let yourself be confined to conventional lenses, either. Specialty lenses like a fisheye can bring a whole new perspective to your shots, distorting reality in a visually interesting way. The key is to let go of preconceptions. Let your creativity lead the way.

13. Don't be afraid of bad weather

A landscape scene can change dramatically depending on the weather – so it's essential that you plan ahead and carefully pick your time and location.

As I emphasized above, partial cloud cover at sunrise and sunset makes for a stunning sky (and partial cloud cover looks great during the blue hour, too!). But other types of weather are great for landscape photography, including:

  • Fog
  • Rain
  • Dark, heavy clouds
  • Snow
  • Rainbows

Unfortunately, many of these weather events don't last very long, so it's important that you always keep one eye on the forecast. And if you do expect fog, snow, or storms, choose your location in advance. Fog and snow look great in forest scenes, while rain and stormy clouds can dramatically enhance beach and ocean shots.

Pro tip: Bad weather, while highly photogenic, can be dangerous! Always tell a friend or family member where you plan to go, always wear proper protective gear, and bring proper protective gear for your equipment, too. I recommend a waterproof camera cover, though you can always get away with a modified trash bag plus some rubber bands (to secure it around the lens).

14. Photograph the landscape at night

Night photography is like stepping into a whole new realm, and while I can't cover it entirely here, I can give you enough to get started.

You see, night scenes offer a celestial spectacle, but they require some special skills and gear. First and foremost, know your location. Scouting becomes even more vital when you can only use a flashlight to illuminate potential compositions.

A sturdy tripod is your best friend for night photography. Long exposures are essential to capture the low light, and any camera shake will ruin the shot. You're likely to use shutter speeds of 20 seconds or more, so make sure your tripod can handle the job.

Interested in astrophotography? A wide-angle lens with a fast aperture, like f/2.8, can be a valuable addition to your kit. This setup allows you to capture the night sky while keeping star movement to a minimum. To achieve this, you might need to ramp up your ISO settings to around 1600 or higher. But don't worry, the night sky is forgiving when it comes to noise.

15. Shoot after (or during) a snowfall

Few scenes are as enchanting as a snow-covered landscape. The world seems to pause, wrapped in a soft white blanket. However, capturing these winter wonderlands comes with its own set of challenges. For starters, your camera will need some extra care. If the snow is still falling while you're shooting, consider using a rain cover for your gear. Keeping a cloth handy to wipe any snow off your lens can also be a lifesaver.

Once you've safeguarded your equipment, it's time to get creative. A snow-covered backdrop can bring out dramatic contrasts. Picture the dark outline of a barren tree against a white sky. The key here is embracing simplicity. A snow-covered scene already feels minimalistic. Don't clutter it; let the snow speak for itself.

Note: Rapid temperature changes can lead to condensation forming on your lens. To avoid this problem when heading back indoors at the end of a shoot, seal your camera in a bag or some airtight compartment before entering the warmth. Once you bring your gear inside, wait for a few hours before opening up your bag; that way, your camera has time to adjust to the indoor temperature.

16. Don't neglect shallow depth of field techniques

Deep depth of field is almost synonymous with landscape photography. You'd generally want everything from the foreground to the horizon in sharp focus. But here's a twist: using a shallow depth of field can give your images an entirely different, magical quality. Opening up your aperture to f/2.8 or f/4 lets in a lot of light and significantly blurs out the background.

The key is to focus attentively on your subject. Let's say you've got a rock or a field of grasses that you want to highlight. Adjust your focus right on it. Then, when you take the shot, the background transforms into a creamy, dreamy blur.

It's not your typical landscape photo, and that's the point. You can create a more intimate, fine-art look that highlights smaller details in a grand landscape.

17. Do black-and-white landscape photography

Color certainly has its charm. The pop of orange in a sunset or the vibrancy of a field of wildflowers can be stunning. Yet, there's something captivating about black-and-white landscape photography. With a focus on contrast, texture, and form, black-and-white photos strip away distractions. They direct your attention to the core of the scene.

In the old days, photographers started with black-and-white because that's all they had. So when you're shooting in monochrome, you're kind of paying homage to the roots of landscape photography. Plus, you don't have to decide right away whether you'll keep the photo in black-and-white. If you're shooting in RAW, which I highly recommend, you can make that choice later during post-processing.

That said, it's useful to consider black-and-white conversion while shooting. Look for elements that will pop in grayscale, such as stark contrasts or intricate textures, and really commit to a monochrome approach!

18. Think about the horizon line

This landscape photography tip is quick and easy:

Always pay attention to the horizon line, and do whatever you can to keep it straight .

A crooked horizon line looks incredibly amateurish, and while you can fix this in post-processing, you'll lose pixels along the edge of the frame – which will reduce your ability to print large and (even worse!) can cut off key compositional elements.

So make sure you get it right in-camera! Here, viewfinder gridlines can be helpful. Most cameras have these activated by default, but if you don't see them, head into the settings menu and switch them on.

And if you use the gridlines but you still struggle to keep things straight, you might consider purchasing a bubble level. You can attach one of these to your camera's hot shoe, and you can use it as a reference when setting up new compositions.

19. Combine light and shadow

You might have heard the saying that photography is the art of painting with light. Well, it's not just about the light; it's also about the shadows. Combining light and shadow in your landscape shots can result in some truly stunning images. The contrast between illuminated areas and dark shadows adds depth, creates mood, and draws the eye to key parts of the frame.

Waiting for the perfect interplay of light and shadow often requires patience. One of the best times to capture this is when the sky is overcast, and the sun is peeking through the clouds. When that ray of sunshine breaks through and lights up a portion of the landscape while leaving the rest in shadow, you've got yourself a golden opportunity.

Another scenario is during sunrise or sunset. Low-angle light naturally creates long shadows and can illuminate just the tops of hills and trees while leaving other areas dark. The contrasting elements give your photo a dynamic, three-dimensional feel that flat lighting just can't achieve.

So, the next time you're out with your camera and the lighting seems challenging, don't pack up. Stick around. Watch the light and shadow dance across the landscape. You might just find that the most captivating shots come when you blend both elements harmoniously.

20. Try HDR techniques

HDR photography sometimes gets a bad rap, largely because of overdone, unrealistic results. But this doesn't mean you should shy away from it. When you're faced with a challenging scene, such as a sunset over the ocean, your camera might not capture the full range of light. That's where HDR comes in handy. The idea is to take multiple shots at different exposure levels. One for the shadows, one for the midtones, and one for the highlights.

Once you've got your series of photos, the next step is blending them together. Software like Adobe Photoshop or Lightroom can merge these images into one.结果？ A photo with details in both the darkest and brightest areas, much like how our eyes perceive the world.

But remember, subtlety is your friend. It's easy to go overboard with contrast and saturation sliders. Less is often more when it comes to HDR in landscape photography. Aim for a balanced, natural look to bring out the best in your photos.

21. Change your point of view

Are you looking to capture strikingly unique landscape images?

Then you've got to move past those basic “lookout” shots, where you point your camera at a beautiful scene, then snap a photo.

Instead, take a little more time with each landscape scene. In particular, look for an interesting angle or point of view, where you approach the composition from an interesting direction. You should have fun with this; try getting down low, finding a high vantage point, walking off to the left or the right, or even shooting from directly above (see the next tip!).

Often, these unconventional images are astonishingly powerful, in part because they show the landscape from a never-before-seen perspective.

It's important to bear in mind, however, that you should still pay careful attention to your gear and lighting. A unique perspective can add a lot to an image, but the best landscape shots combine well-chosen gear, great lighting, and a great perspective for a beautiful result.

22. Capture aerial landscape images

Taking your photography to the sky opens up a new world of possibilities. Aerial landscape photography has grown in popularity, thanks largely to the accessibility of drones. These nifty flying cameras allow you to capture views that were once only possible from helicopters or planes.

But capturing great aerial shots isn't as easy as simply sending a drone up and hitting the shutter button. It's an art form that has its own rules and challenges. Your composition skills are more important than ever. After all, from up high, you can see patterns and shapes that are invisible from ground level. Rivers look like veins, roads like stitches, and forests like broccoli!

When you're starting out with aerial photography, I recommend studying the work of other drone photographers. Look for elements that make their shots effective. Is it the angle? The lighting? The way they've framed a particular landscape feature? As you dissect these factors, you'll find it easier to replicate them in your own work.

Of course, safety and legality are paramount. Always abide by the rules governing drone use in your area. Most countries have regulations about where you can and can't fly, and some require a license. Make sure you're informed before taking off.

Once you're up there, the sky's the limit—literally. Whether you're capturing the intricate patterns of a cityscape or the sweeping vistas of a mountain range, aerial photography brings a fresh perspective to landscapes. With some practice and a good eye for composition, you'll be creating jaw-dropping images in no time.

23. Don't forget to edit your landscape photos

If you shoot digital—and most of us do these days—editing isn't optional; it's essential. Don't think of editing as cheating or as something that sullies the “purity” of your photos. Trust me, even the best photos can benefit from a little post-processing.

Imagine editing as the final brushstroke in your creative process. Sure, you can get great shots straight out of the camera, but they'll almost always look better with a bit of tweaking. Simple things like adjusting exposure, white balance, and contrast can make a world of difference. These basic tweaks aim to make the photo match what your eyes saw. That's what we call “getting it right in camera.”
